dhs.utils.create_func_dict module

dhs.utils.create_func_dict.create_func_dict() → dict[source]

Create dictionary with summary metrics.

This function creates a dictionary that contains the median and the standard deviation of the median for each column of a DataFrame.

Returns:

Dictionary with pd.Series.

Return type:

dict

static create_cauchy(noise: float, seq: list) → ndarray[source]

Create Cauchy density.

This function creates the marginal density of the Cauchy prior.

Parameters:

  • noise (float) – Noise variance.

  • seq (list) – Sequence (domain) of the figure.

Returns:

Cauchy density.

Return type:

np.ndarray

static create_dhs_rhs(kind: str, n_samples: int, n_vars: int, n_obs: int, noise: float, trunc: float, seed: int, spars: float | None = None, frac_rel_vars: float | None = None) → ndarray[source]

Create Dirichlet-horseshoe or regularized horseshoe density.

This function creates the marginal density of the Dirichlet-horseshoe prior or the regularized horseshoe prior.

Parameters:

  • kind (str) – Kind of density (dhs or rhs).

  • n_samples (int) – Number of samples.

  • n_vars (int) – Number of variables.

  • n_obs (int) – Number of observations.

  • noise (float) – Noise variance.

  • trunc (float) – Truncation.

  • seed (int) – Random seed.

  • spars (float, optional) – Sparsity level.

  • frac_rel_vars (float, optional) – Fraction of relevant variables.

Returns:

Selected density.

Return type:

np.ndarray

static create_dl(a: float, seq_j: float) → ndarray[source]

Create Dirichlet-Laplace density.

This function creates the marginal density of the Dirichlet-Laplace prior.

Parameters:

  • a (float) – Concentration rate.

  • seq_j (float) – Element of the sequence (domain) to be plotted.

Returns:

Dirichlet-Laplace density.

Return type:

np.ndarray

static create_hs(seq: list, bound: str = 'upper') → ndarray[source]

Create horseshoe density.

This function creates the marginal density of the horseshoe prior.

Parameters:

  • seq (list) – The sequence (domain) to be plotted.

  • bound (str, default upper) – Lower/upper bound.

Returns:

Horseshoe density.

Return type:

np.ndarray

format_post(value)[source]

Format a column of a DataFrame according to a specified format.

This function attempts to convert the input value to a numeric value. If the conversion is successful, it formats the value to have the specific format. If the conversion fails (due to a ValueError or TypeError), it returns the original value unchanged.

Parameters:

value (_type_) – Input value to be formatted.

Returns:

Formatted value.

Return type:

_type_

dhs.utils.plot_posteriors module

dhs.utils.plot_posteriors.plot_posteriors(mdl_trace: InferenceData, n_states: int, li_vars_plot: list, li_cues: list, fig_path: str, fig_name: str, save: bool) → None[source]

Plot posterior distributions.

Parameters:

  • mdl_trace (az.InferenceData) – Record of the sampling process.

  • n_states (int) – Number of states.

  • li_vars_plot (list) – List of variables to be plotted.

  • li_cues (list) – List of emotional cues.

  • fig_path (str) – Figure path.

  • fig_name (str) – Figure name.

  • save (bool) – Save objects.

dhs.utils.run_sampler module

dhs.utils.run_sampler.run_sampler(model: Model, n_draws: int, n_tune: int, n_chains: int, seed: int, targ_acpt: float, *args, **kwargs) → InferenceData[source]

Run the sampler.

This function numerically estimates the defined PyMC model using Hamiltonian Monte Carlo methods (NUTS). The output (trace) object keeps track of the sampled values of each variable over the course of the sampling process and can be used to calculate summary statistics, to draw posterior distributions, and to diagnose convergence, for example.

Parameters:

  • model (pm.Model) – PyMC model to be estimated.

  • n_draws (int) – Number of draws.

  • n_tune (int) – Number of tuning samples (burn-in).

  • n_chains (int) – Number of chains.

  • seed (int) – Random seed.

  • targ_acpt (float) – Target acceptance rate.

  • *args (non-keyword arguments) – Parameters specific to the trace.

  • **kwargs (keyword arguments) – Parameters specific to the trace.

Returns:

Record of the sampling process.

Return type:

arviz.InferenceData

dhs.utils.write_text_file module

dhs.utils.write_text_file.write_text_file(file: str, body: str, first_line: None | int = 1, last_line: None | int = -1) → None[source]

Write text to a text file.

This function can be particulary useful to store TeX table code in a text file. For example, the first and the last line can be stripped to embed the file within a TeX tabular environment.

Parameters:

  • file (str) – Name (path) of file.

  • body (str) – Text to write.

  • first_line (int | None, default 1) – First line to write.

  • last_line (int | None, default -1) – Last line to write.

Return type:

None

See also

pandas.DataFrame.to_latex

Render object to a LaTeX tabular, longtable, or nested table.

Examples

>>> df = pd.DataFrame({"A": [1.5, 0.1234], "B": [-2, 15000]})
>>> df.head()
...
        A      B
0  1.5000     -2
1  0.1234  15000
>>> write_text_file(
        file="df.tex",
        body=df.to_latex(),
        first_line=1,
        last_line=-1
    )

static create_dhs_rhs(kind: str, n_samples: int, n_vars: int, n_obs: int, noise: float, trunc: float, seed: int, spars: float | None = None, frac_rel_vars: float | None = None) → ndarray[source]

Create Dirichlet-horseshoe or regularized horseshoe density.

This function creates the marginal density of the Dirichlet-horseshoe prior or the regularized horseshoe prior.

Parameters:

  • kind (str) – Kind of density (dhs or rhs).

  • n_samples (int) – Number of samples.

  • n_vars (int) – Number of variables.

  • n_obs (int) – Number of observations.

  • noise (float) – Noise variance.

  • trunc (float) – Truncation.

  • seed (int) – Random seed.

  • spars (float, optional) – Sparsity level.

  • frac_rel_vars (float, optional) – Fraction of relevant variables.

Returns:

Selected density.

Return type:

np.ndarray
